questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the normal metabolism of vitamin B12? A. Haptocorrin from salivary glands binds to B12 in the stomach. B. It is absorbed in the duodenum with the help of intrinsic factor and transcobalamin II. C. Gastric enzymes play an important role in splitting of haptocorrin-B12 complex. D. It is stored primarily in the liver and has a large reserve capacity. E. It acts as a cofactor for converting homocysteine to methionine and methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) A, D, and E Explanation: Vitamin B12 Absorption and Transport: Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the terminal ileum (Option B). Haptocorrin , secreted by the salivary gland , binds to B12 in the stomach and enters the duodenum (Option A) . Haptocorrin is separated from B12 by pancreatic enzymes and binds to IF (Option C) . Absorbed B12 is transported by transcobalamin II (Option B) . Stored primarily in the liver and has a large reserve capacity to last several years (Option D) . Vitamin B12 is a cofactor for: (Option E) Conversion of homocysteine to methionine. Methyl malonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA.

questions.question: All of the following are the causes of anaemia due to vitamin B12 deficiency, except?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Chronic alcoholism Explanation: Chronic alcoholism causes megaloblastic anaemia due to folate deficiency. Causes of Vitamin B12 deficiency: Reduced Dietary Intake Increased demand Impaired Absorption Vegetarian diet Pregnancy Lactation Growing child Pernicious anemia (Option A) Infections- Diphyllobothrium latum (Option C) Gastrectomy (Option:D) Ileal disorders Malabsorption Ileal resection Diverticula of bowel Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 651

questions.question: A 60-year-old female presents with chronic fatigue, shortness of breath, tingling and numbness in her hands and feet, bloating, and epigastric pain after meals. She has a history of occasional heartburn and nausea. On examination, she is pale, has a smooth, enlarged tongue with the following findings on the hand. Lab investigations show haemoglobin to be 9.6 g% and MCV 112. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Pernicious anaemia Explanation: Pernicious anaemia is the likely diagnosis due to macrocytic anaemia (high MCV), chronic fatigue, neurological symptoms (tingling and numbness), and gastrointestinal issues (bloating and epigastric pain). The physical signs of pallor and a smooth, enlarged tongue, along with the image of knuckle hyperpigmentation further indicate vitamin B12 deficiency, characteristic of pernicious anaemia. Pernicious Anemia: Pernicious anaemia is a specific form of megaloblastic anaemia caused by autoimmune gastritis that impairs the production of the intrinsic factor required for vitamin B12 uptake from the gut. Three types of antibodies: Type 1: Inhibit B12 binding to intrinsic factor . Type 2: Inhibit B12-IF binding to iliac cubilin receptors. Type 3: Target parietal cells. Clinical features : Fatigue and pallor. Hyperpigmentation : Mainly on knuckles and interphalangeal areas. Atrophic glossitis (beefy red smooth tongue). Atrophic gastritis (due to antibodies against parietal cells). Increased gastric adenocarcinoma risk. Neurological manifestations: Subacute combined degeneration of the spinal tract. Both sensory and motor loss (combined degeneration) Headache, fatigue , impaired balance , paresthesia, muscle weakness and neuropathy . Blood smear: Iron deficiency anaemia typically presents with microcytic anaemia (Option A) . Folate deficiency can present with macrocytic anaemia but is less likely to cause neurological symptoms and knuckle hyperpigmentation (Option B) .

questions.question: Match the following laboratory findings with the most likely diagnosis. a. Microcytic anaemia, normal homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels. 1. Vitamin B12 Deficiency b. Macrocytic anaemia, elevated homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels. 2. Iron Deficiency Anemia (IDA) c. Macrocytic anaemia, elevated homocysteine and normal methylmalonic acid levels. 3. Anaemia of Chronic Disease (ACD) d. Normocytic anaemia, normal homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels. 4. Folate Deficiency
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) a-2, b-1, c-4, d-3 Explanation: Disease Lab Findings Blood Smear Vitamin B12 Deficiency RBC Indices: Hemoglobin(Hb): low. MCV: high (> 100fL). MCH: high. MCHC: normal. Homocysteine: Low Methylmalonic acid: Low. Macrocytic hyperchromic anemia. Folate Deficiency RBC Indices: Hemoglobin(Hb): low. MCV: high (> 100fL). MCH: high. MCHC: normal. Homocysteine: Low Methylmalonic acid: Normal. Iron deficiency anaemia & anaemia of chronic disease (AOCD): Microcytic hypochromic anaemia is seen (AOCD: Normocytic normochromic > microcytic hypochromic). Homocysteine & methylmalonic acid levels are normal.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a finding on a peripheral blood smear in vitamin B12 deficiency? A. B. C. D.
questions.explanation: multiple irregularly shaped and randomly distributed cytoplasmic projections. Associated conditions: Abetalipoproteinemia. Cirrhosis. Chronic hepatitis. Renal failure. Peripheral blood smear findings in megaloblastic anaemia: Blood Smear Findings Associated Disease Macrocytosis (Option A) Enlarged oddly shaped RBC MCV > 100fL Alcoholism Megaloblastic anaemia Pregnancy Aplastic anemia Hypothyroidism. Cabot ring (Option B) Arginine-rich mitotic spindle Figure of 8" shaped inclusions Basophilic stippling in the erythrocyte. Thalassaemia Megaloblastic anaemia Lead poisoning Howell-Jolly body (Option C) DNA or nuclear remnants in the erythrocyte. Megaloblastic anaemia Post-splenectomy Hemolytic anaemia

questions.question: All the following findings are seen in vitamin B12 deficiency except?

options.B: Sieve-like chromatin on bone marrow smear

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Myeloid/erythroid ratio is 3:1 Explanation: The normal myeloid: erythroid ratio is 3:1. In vitamin B12 deficiency, a reversal of myeloid: erythroid ratio is seen (1:3). Important Laboratory findings associated with Vitamin B12 deficiency: Bone Marrow Biochemical Tests Hypercellular bone marrow Erythroid Hyperplasia Sieve-like chromatin (Option: B) . Hypersegmented neutrophils Reversal of myeloid: erythroid ratio 1:1 or less (Normal: 3:1) (Option A) Nuclear-cytoplasmic asynchrony Serum bilirubin: Increases (Option: D) . Serum LDH: Increases (Option: C) . Vitamin B12: Decreases Folic acid: Decreases Anti-Intrinsic Factor (IF) antibody: Present (Pernicious anemia) Methylmalonyl CoA: Increases Homocysteine: Increases Schilling Test: Assess cause of B12 deficiency. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 651-655

questions.question: A patient presents with tiredness and myalgia for the past 3 months. She has hypertension, psoriasis and hyperuricemia, for which she is on multiple medications. A peripheral blood smear is done which is given in the image below. Which of her following medications would have caused these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Methotrexate Explanation: The peripheral blood smear shows enlarged oval-shaped red blood cells (macro-ovalocytes) with hyperchromia and hypersegmented neutrophils. This suggests megaloblastic anaemia , which in this scenario would be due to folate deficiency caused by methotrexate. Common causes of folate deficiency are given below : Decreased intake Inadequate diet. Alcoholism. Infancy. Impaired absorption Malabsorption states. Intrinsic intestinal disease. Anticonvulsants, oral contraceptives. Increased loss Haemodialysis. Increased requirement Pregnancy. Infancy. Disseminated cancer. Markedly increased hematopoiesis. Impaired utilisation Folic acid antagonists (Methotrexate). Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 651

questions.question: Which of the following helps differentiate megaloblastic anaemia caused by vitamin B12 deficiency, not folate?

options.B: Neurological symptoms improve after folate administration
options.D: Anaemia doesn’t improve after folate administration

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Raised urinary methylmalonic acid levels Explanation: Plasma and urinary methylmalonic acid levels will be elevated in case of vitamin B12 deficiency but not with folate deficiency. This is because the enzyme methylmalonyl coenzyme A mutase's isomerisation of methylmalonyl coenzyme A to succinyl coenzyme A requires adenosylcobalamin (a form of vitamin B12) as a cofactor. A deficiency of vitamin B12 thus leads to increased plasma and urine levels of methylmalonic acid. Vitamin B12 is key in converting homocysteine to methionine; hence, its deficiency will lead to elevated homocysteine levels (Option A) rather than reduction. Neurological symptoms will remain the same, if not worsen, after folate administration in case of Vitamin B12 deficient megaloblastic anaemia (Option B) . Improvement in symptoms and reduction in megaloblastic count occur after folate administration, even if the anaemia is due to Vitamin B12 deficiency (Option D) . Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 653, 654

questions.question: Which of the following is true when increased urinary formiminoglutamic acid is detected in a patient to whom histidine is given?

options.A: Presence of antibodies against intrinsic factor
options.B: Deficiency of folic acid is present

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Deficiency of folic acid is present Explanation: Elevated urinary levels of formiminoglutamic acid (FIGlu) in a patient to whom histidine is given suggests the presence of folic acid deficiency . This is called the FIGlu test. Folic acid is normally required in its tetrahydrofolate form to regulate DNA synthesis and the production of methionine, glutamate, etc. Formiminoglutamic acid derived from histidine will be converted to glutamate in the presence of folic acid. If there is a folic acid deficiency, this conversion will not occur, leading to elevated urinary formiminoglutamic acid. Presence of antibodies against intrinsic factor (Option A): Antibodies to intrinsic factor will be seen in pernicious anaemia in which there will be vitamin B12 deficiency. Neurological symptoms are common (Option C): Neurological symptoms will be seen in Vitamin B12 deficiency , not folate deficiency. Reference: The role of the FIGLU test in identifying folate deficiency, as folic acid plays a very significant role in purine synthesis, and folate deficiency leads to defective DNA signalling, leading to megaloblastosis

questions.question: A patient presents with inflammation of the mouth and tongue. He is a non-vegetarian. As part of the evaluation, a Schilling test was done and found unremarkable. Which of the following investigations could lead to the aetiology behind this presentation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Serum folate levels Explanation: It is a scenario of possible megaloblastic anaemia due to folate deficiency. Hence, serum/red cell folate can lead to the aetiology behind this presentation. Schilling test is done by orally administering the patient with radioactive vitamin B12 and checking its presence in the urine. If present, as with this case, it is understood that there is no problem with the absorption. In addition to an unremarkable Schilling test, the fact that vitamin B12 deficiency is uncommon among non-vegetarians suggests a diagnosis of folate-deficient megaloblastic anaemia. Stage of test 24-hour urinary excretion of radiolabelled B12 Inference Stage 1: Oral radiolabelled B12 + IM dose of unlabelled B12 (to saturate liver stores) >10% (Normal) Malnutrition <10% Stage 2 of the test is done Stage 2: Oral radiolabelled B12 + Intrinsic factor >10% Pernicious anaemia <10% Stage 3 of the test is done Stage 3: Oral radiolabelled B12 + Antibiotics (5-day course) >10% Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth <10% Stage 4 of the test is done Stage 4: Oral radiolabelled B12 + Recombinant pancreatic enzymes >10% Pancreatic insufficiency (Cystic fibrosis, chronic pancreatitis) <10% Consider other ileal diseases Peripheral blood smear (Option B) may exhibit megalocytes with hyper-segmented neutrophils suggestive of megaloblastic anaemia, but the aetiology cannot be identified based on this. Anti-IF (intrinsic factor) antibodies (Option C) are found in patients with pernicious anaemia, and since the Schilling test is unremarkable, it can be ruled out. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 654, 655 Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 771
